job_title: English Language Tutor in Spokane, WA
pros: 1.Flexibility: English language tutoring often offers flexible working hours, allowing you to set your own schedule and work at times that are convenient for you. This can be especially beneficial if you have other commitments or responsibilities. 2.Fulfilling and rewarding: Helping students improve their English language skills can be highly fulfilling and rewarding. Witnessing their progress and seeing them gain confidence in their abilities can be incredibly gratifying. 3.Cultural exchange: English language tutoring provides an opportunity for cultural exchange, as you may work with students from different countries and backgrounds. This can broaden your worldview and increase your intercultural competence. 4.Personal and professional development: As an English language tutor, you can further develop your own language skills, teaching techniques, and communication abilities. You may also gain valuable experience in working with diverse learners and enhancing your interpersonal skills.
cons: 1.Limited income potential: The pay for English language tutoring may not always be as high as other professions, especially if you are working as a freelance tutor or in a less affluent area. Income can be irregular and unstable, depending on the number of students and the demand for English language tutoring.

pros:
The pay and benefits are competitive. 
Some departments function better than others. 
They have a great basketball team. 
The students are wonderful. The campus is beautiful.
cons: There is a lack of adequate teaching and office space. My department consistently has seen out-of-control enrollments with no additional resources provided. Our course sections have nearly doubled since I started working here. There seems to be a lack of concern about the quality of instruction, and more concern about increasing the number of students. The workload is daunting and many complain that their work-life balance is poor. It seems to be run like a for-profit business which pretends to be not-for-profit. Promotions are based upon cronyism and not upon merit. Loyalty and excellent service are not rewarded, and preference is to hire external, unknown candidates instead of promoting from within. Accomplishments are not equitably recognized. This is a "pay to play" culture. I was initially attracted by the seemingly positive environment based upon Jesuit values, but I do not see this anymore. Since 2009, I have seen the quality of education suffer. Faculty retention has been poor. I am looking elsewhere for employment.

pros: Flexible, good community, ability to advance skills

review_title: Good Campus, Horrible Housing Dept. Culture
job_title: Resident Assistant in South Seattle, WA
pros:
I am a student and a former employee of Gonzaga University. I don't want this to sound like a rebuttal against Gonzaga itself, just the department that I worked for. I love many things about it:
The Humanistic Approach to life
Caring Culture
Friendly and Engaging Community
Great Religious Groups and Help
Cool Campus Architecture
Fun residents and classmates, generally positive people
cons:
Here come the downsides. Working in Housing is horrible. Like incredibly horrible. I could write a lot here, so I'll just make a list: 
Far Left political views are shoved down your throat at every turn
Many of the managers are incompetent and incredibly biased
Meetings that are complete wastes of time and energy
Events that have no department support
Pay is based on online reporting and other administrative tasks, not actual performance
Discipline is convoluted, confusing, and inefficient- several times I got in trouble for writing people up when THEY HAD ALCOHOL in their hands
Incompetent RAs get promoted based on kissing up to the bosses
Residents are often viewed as the last priority, even when they should be our first

Finally, myself and other RAs came together and created a document to solve many of these problems, yet upper management simply ignored us. Housing is still woefully inefficient and slow at the most mundane tasks.

review_title: Thriving, unique and welcoming community,  both students and professors alike
job_title: University Representative Telefund Caller in Spokane, WA
pros: Working part-time as a university representative was an overall excellent experience. Can be a fairly challenging job at first, but grows more manageable over time. Co-workers are all students, so you will most likely be working with familiar faces or have an opportunity to meet some new people. The higher-ups are all former students as well, and are very supportive, even after graduation.
cons: Cold calling can be difficult even if everyone has *some* connection to the university. There are always those malignant folks who enjoy giving you a hard time, but for every insulting call, there are five great ones.

review_title: Mixed bag, depends on a lot of factors
pros: Being a professor is one of the best jobs out there! You get to set your hours, teach three or four courses a semester, and spend the rest of your time conducting your research, serving on various university committees, working with students, grading exams, etc.
cons: The administration is top heavy and our men's basketball coach earns over $3 million a year before endorsements! It is easy to see where they spend their money. Professor pay depends greatly on which department they teach in and what level.

review_title: Being a Doctoral researcher has been fulfilling.
pros: It complements my doctoral studies and enhances my research skills. It builds on my knowledge and skills in Leadership development and organizational leadership.
cons: As an international student, I can only work 20 hours a week. My international work experience does not fit in the structure of the institution and works against me in my job search within the university.

pros: I am very fortunate in that, as a Graduate Assistant, I work for a professor who gives me a fixed set of hours per week, but allows me to allocate them throughout the week as I choose.
cons: It is not really applicable to my status as an employee, but rather as a student.  The Internet and IT is terrible, and it sometimes interfere with my ability to my job properly.

review_title: A great first job with a friendly work environment.
job_title: Assistant to the Purchasing Manager in Spokane, WA
pros: The university puts a great amount of effort into providing a comfortable and productive work environment for its many faculty and staff.  They are particularly interested in the education of students, allowing for significant flexibility in work hours.  The people are all really great to work with.
cons: They do not have any openings for  students of the Applied Sciences besides faculty positions so it is really only good as a starting job for non-business students.

job_title: IT Service Technician in Spokane, WA
pros: The office was full of friendly folks who truly wanted to help everyone who comes in. We had multiple luncheons and lots of appreciation for their employees, part time or full.
cons: Despite such competence, there is a huge lack of training, luckily I didn't need it, but other employees could have definitely used it and it showed to the customers who came in. The only reason they receive a top 50 is because the staff is so friendly and work as hard as they can to solve the problem, even if they don't possess the knowledge to do so.

pros: Fantastic environment, they really love working with you and pushing you to be the best you can be. I really love working there.
cons: Not a whole lot of downsides, but I would say that the biggest is probably the lack of hours. I am signed up for 15 hours a week, and I am getting 5-7 hours, which is fine as a student

review_title: I love Gonzaga, working for my school was a great experience!
pros: As a work study, you get a great schedule and get to experience life in an office setting while taking classes. My boss and co-workers were great! Even though I was a part-time worker, I felt respected and appreciated. Some days were busy, but not all. Life in the office was laid back. As a student I would highly recommend working for your school.
cons: Not much to say here, the job wasn't difficult and I really enjoyed being around the people from my department.

job_title: Residence Life Desk Manager in Spokane, WA
pros: My favorite part about working at Gonzaga University was the opportunity to interact with students and utilize the endless resources the school provides.
cons: Lack of diversity in students and staff members. Gonzaga also feels like its own "bubble" at times, so it was important for me to get off of campus at times and see the rest of Spokane.

review_title: Great place as a student if you know which department to work...

pros: The Gonzaga community is very special--Everyone is treated with respect, and everyone seems to be treated as one big family. There is room to grow and opportunities to advance. As a full-time employee, you can even go to school for free!
